title: Lance P. Sijan USAF Leadership Award
content: Recognizes Air Force officers and enlisted members who demonstrate the highest qualities of leadership in the performance of their duties and in their lives, exemplifying Capt Lance P. Sijan's courage, integrity, perseverance, and self-sacrifice. [1]
bullets: Named in honor of **Capt Lance P. Sijan**, Medal of Honor recipient and first USAFA graduate to receive the medal. [1]
One of the Air Force's **most prestigious leadership awards**, created to recognize leadership in the spirit of Sijan's example. [2]
Awarded annually to four Airmen: senior officer, junior officer, senior enlisted, and junior enlisted. [2]
Nominees must show **sustained outstanding leadership**, not just a single act, in both duty performance and personal conduct. [2]

title: Outstanding Airman of the Year (12 Outstanding Airmen of the Year)
content: Recognizes 12 enlisted Airmen each year for exceptional primary duty performance, leadership, and embodiment of the Whole Airman Concept. [3]
bullets: Air Force-level program that selects 12 enlisted members annually as the service's **top Airmen**. [3]
Primary evaluation criteria are **superior job performance**, leadership, followership, and personal achievements reflecting the Whole Airman Concept. [3]
Nominees compete first at the MAJCOM/FOA/DRU/COCOM level before moving to an Air Force selection board. [3]
The nomination period normally covers a single calendar year. [4]

title: First Sergeant of the Year
content: Recognizes the Air Force's top first sergeant for exceptional leadership, mentorship, and care of Airmen and families while maintaining unit readiness. [4]
bullets: Honors a first sergeant who serves as the key leader for readiness, health, morale, welfare, and quality-of-life issues. [4]
Recognizes outstanding performance in building and maintaining a **mission-ready force** at home and in expeditionary environments. [5]
Selection is based on **leadership impact**, readiness initiatives, discipline, and community involvement. [5]
Typically, one Air Force-level winner is chosen annually from MAJCOM and other major-organization nominees. [5]

title: AFSOC Commander's Leadership Award
content: Recognizes Air Commandos selected by their commanders for exceptional leadership and significant contributions to AFSOC mission accomplishment. [6]
bullets: Sponsored by the **Air Commando Association** in coordination with AFSOC leadership. [6]
Honors outstanding performers from any AFSC or career field who made the most significant contributions to mission execution. [6]
Recipients are selected at the unit, wing, or AFSOC level. [6]
Typical achievements include **leading large teams** or enabling high-risk special operations. [7]

title: AFSOC Outstanding Special Operations Squadron of the Year
content: Recognizes the most outstanding AFSOC squadron based on operational performance, combat impact, and overall contribution to AFSOC missions. [7, 8]
bullets: Eligibility includes all active duty, AFRC, and ANG operational flying, support, and special tactics squadrons. [8]
Selection is based on **combat readiness**, mission synopsis, individual accomplishments, and community relations. [8]
Evaluation includes combat deployments and mission execution in contingency operations. [9]
Considers how the squadron maintained readiness and **innovated tactics** in support of global SOF operations. [9]
The winning squadron receives a trophy for permanent retention. [10]

title: General Billy J. Boles Mentorship Award
content: Honors individuals in the A1 community who put forth great effort in mentoring Airmen to reach higher standards of excellence and foster professional enhancement. [10, 11]
bullets: Any military member or civilian employee in the **A1 community** is eligible. [10]
Recognizes the full scope of what the nominee did for their mentees and the resulting impact. [10]
Exceptional mentors facilitate development and help mentees reach their full potential. [12]
Past winners have been recognized for designing and implementing **deliberate mentorship programs**. [12]
Typically recognizes sustained, documented mentorship that positively affects careers and force development. [13]

title: Lt. Gen. Leo Marquez Maintenance Excellence Award
content: Recognizes Air Force military and civilian maintenance professionals for superior job performance and technical expertise in aircraft, munitions/missile, and communications-electronics maintenance. [12, 14]
bullets: Named after Lt. Gen. Leo Marquez, known as the **'Godfather' of Air Force maintenance**. [14, 15]
It is one of the most prestigious awards in the Air Force maintenance community. [15]
Awarded annually for maintainers who perform **hands-on maintenance** or manage maintenance functions at the base level. [14]
Focuses on sustained job performance, depth of technical knowledge, and direct involvement in sortie generation. [16]

title: General Lew Allen, Jr. Trophy
content: Recognizes accomplishments of base-level officers and SNCOs directly involved in sortie generation and mission execution. [15, 16]
bullets: Named after the 10th Chief of Staff of the Air Force, known for his attention to detail and technical expertise. [17, 18]
Awarded annually to four individuals: two in maintenance and two in logistics. [17]
Strong emphasis on **leadership in maintenance operations**, sortie production metrics, and innovation in support of high-tempo flying. [18]
MAJCOMs nominate candidates based on accomplishments over a defined award period. [18]

title: Maintenance Effectiveness Award
content: Recognizes maintenance units that most successfully manage resources to provide safe, serviceable equipment for sustained use in peacetime and wartime. [19, 20]
bullets: Awarded annually with categories for small-aircraft, medium-aircraft, missile/munitions maintenance, and depot. [20]
Focuses on overall unit management of people, funds, and equipment to achieve high **mission-capable rates**. [20]
Considers safety, innovation, inspection results, and support to operations across exercises and deployments. [21]
Aims to maximize readiness and recognize the best maintenance teams. [19]

title: CMSAF Thomas N. Barnes Crew Chief of the Year Award
content: Recognizes the top Air Force dedicated crew chief who exhibits the highest levels of readiness, efficiency, and excellence. [21, 22]
bullets: Named for Thomas N. Barnes, the **first African American Chief Master Sergeant of the Air Force**. [22, 23]
Awarded annually to the single best dedicated crew chief across all aircraft platforms. [23]
Selection criteria emphasize technical excellence, aircraft mission-capable rates, and contributions to safety. [23]
The award is open to crew chiefs across all Air Force components. [24]

title: Mackay Trophy
content: Awarded annually for the 'most meritorious flight of the year' by an Air Force person, persons, or organization. [24, 25]
bullets: Established in 1911 by Clarence H. Mackay and administered by the National Aeronautic Association. [24, 25]
Recognizes a single flight judged most meritorious in terms of **airmanship, risk, and contribution** to aviation progress. [25]
Recognizes gallantry, intrepidity, and unusual initiative under combat or non-combat conditions. [24]
The trophy is housed in the **Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum**. [26]

title: Cheney Award
content: Awarded to an Airman for an act of valor, extreme fortitude, or self-sacrifice in a humanitarian interest, performed in connection with aircraft. [26, 27]
bullets: Established in 1927 in memory of 1st Lt. William H. Cheney. [26, 28]
Award is aviation-focused but not restricted to combat; humanitarian acts are central. [28]
The act does not necessarily have to be of a military nature. [26]
Recent recipients have included crews executing **high-risk rescue missions** under extreme conditions. [28]

title: Staff Sgt. Henry E. 'Red' Erwin Enlisted Aircrew Member of the Year Award
content: Recognizes enlisted aircrew members whose performance, leadership, and professionalism reflect the heroism of Medal of Honor recipient Red Erwin. [29, 30]
bullets: Named for SSgt Henry E. Erwin, who saved his B-29 crew by disposing of a burning bomb despite catastrophic burns. [30]
Recognizes enlisted aircrew (1AXXX or 1UXXX) for contributions to the mission and the Air Force. [31]
Typically awards one junior Airman, one NCO, and one SNCO each year. [30]
Criteria include leadership, job performance, self-improvement, and community involvement. [31]

title: The Daedalian Exceptional Pilot Award
content: Recognizes a military pilot for exceptional airmanship, valor, or resourcefulness in air operations. [31, 32]
bullets: Presented annually by the **Order of Daedalians**, a fraternal order of military pilots. [33, 34]
Awarded for demonstrating outstanding situational awareness, often during an in-flight emergency. [33]
The pilot's actions must have resulted in the **safe recovery of the aircraft and crew**. [33]
Nominees are typically frontline aviators whose actions significantly exceeded expectations. [34]

title: AFSOC SrA Julian S. Scholten ISR Operator of the Year Award
content: Recognizes the most outstanding Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) operator supporting AFSOC combat operations. [35, 36]
bullets: Named in honor of SrA Julian S. Scholten, an ISR operator killed in action in 2012. [35, 36]
Typical accomplishments include creating or improving ISR training and mission planning. [37]
Recognizes expertise, dedication, and impact on special operations forces. [35]
Presented annually at the **Air Commando Association convention**. [35, 37]

title: Spirit of Hope Award
content: Presented to individuals or organizations that epitomize the values of Bob Hope: duty, honor, courage, loyalty, commitment, integrity, and selfless dedication. [38, 39]
bullets: Named after comedian and actor Bob Hope for his decades of service entertaining U.S. troops. [38, 39]
Recognizes those who have selflessly contributed to the well-being of service members and their families. [38]
Each branch of the armed forces, including the Air Force, selects one recipient annually. [38, 40]
The award is presented at a **Pentagon ceremony**. [41]

title: Air Force Medical Service (AFMS) Annual Awards
content: A series of awards recognizing excellence in the medical field, honoring individuals and teams for contributions to patient care, innovation, and readiness. [40, 41]
bullets: Run by the Air Force Surgeon General to honor top medical officers, enlisted medics, and teams. [42]
Awards recognize achievements in areas like clinical dentistry, nursing, public health, and aerospace medicine. [41, 42]
Selection is based on leadership, job performance, and commitment to **trusted, high-quality care**. [42, 43]

title: Air Force Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) Awards
content: Recognizes individuals and units for outstanding performance and contributions to the Air Force's global ISR enterprise. [43, 44]
bullets: Often referred to as the Air Force ISR Awards Program or **AFISRAP**. [44]
Categories include analysts, operators, and support personnel at both individual and unit levels. [44, 45]
Criteria typically focus on mission impact, innovation, and support to joint national intelligence missions. [45, 46]

title: Air Force Security Forces Annual Awards
content: A program to recognize the outstanding performance of Security Forces personnel and units across the Air Force. [46, 47]
bullets: Includes unit-level awards like Outstanding Security Forces Unit of the Year (Large, Medium, Small). [48]
Unit awards assess duty performance, innovation in training, and deployment contributions. [48]
Evaluation criteria include leadership, mission accomplishment, and community involvement. [47]

title: Air Force Cyberspace and Electronic Warfare (EW) Awards
content: Honors individuals and teams who have demonstrated excellence and innovation in cyberspace operations and electronic warfare. [49, 50]
bullets: Includes **General John P. Jumper Awards** for Excellence in Warfighting Integration. [50]
Recognizes contributions to the development, employment, and defense of cyber and EW capabilities. [49]
Covers cyber operations, C4ISR integration, and ISR fusion for joint operations. [51]

title: GEICO Military Service Award
content: Recognizes enlisted members for significant contributions to safety, accident prevention, and community protection. [52, 53]
bullets: Sponsored by the **GEICO Philanthropic Foundation** since 1988. [52, 53]
Categories include Drug and Alcohol Abuse Prevention, Fire Safety, and Traffic Safety. [53, 54]
Selection is based on noteworthy contributions to military or civilian communities. [54, 55]
One active duty and one Guard/Reserve member from each service are selected annually. [53, 54]

title: AFA Joan Orr Air Force Spouse of the Year Award
content: Recognizes a non-military spouse of an Air Force member for significant contributions to the Air Force community. [54, 55]
bullets: Honors exceptional volunteerism and leadership that improve the quality of life for military families. [56, 57]
The recipient's contributions should have a positive impact on the Air Force and the local community. [56]
The award is presented for actions during the preceding calendar year. [56]

title: AFAS CMSAF Pitsenbarger Award (CCAF Grant)
content: Provides a one-time grant to top Community College of the Air Force (CCAF) graduates pursuing a baccalaureate degree. [56, 58]
bullets: Named in honor of **A1C William H. Pitsenbarger**, a Medal of Honor recipient. [59]
Administered by the Air Force Aid Society and the Air & Space Forces Association. [58, 59]
Applicants must be in the top 5% of their graduating class and accepted into a bachelor's program. [58, 59]
The grant is typically **$750** and intended to help with educational expenses. [58, 59]

title: USO Service Member of the Year
content: Honors service members from each branch who show extraordinary heroism, valor, and dedication to duty. [60, 61]
bullets: Recipients are nominated by command leadership for exemplary service. [60, 62]
Recognized actions typically involve **saving lives** or responding to emergencies. [62]
Honorees are celebrated at the annual USO Gala in Washington, D.C. [60, 62]

title: Air Force Innovation Award
content: Recognizes Airmen for innovative ideas that improve processes, save resources, and enhance mission effectiveness. [63, 64]
bullets: Established in 2015 to honor former Vice Chief of Staff **Gen Larry O. Spencer**. [64]
Recognizes both an individual and a team awardee each year for scalable innovations. [64]
Focuses on grassroots innovations from Airmen at all levels. [63, 65]
Criteria include feasibility, impact, and **return on investment**. [65, 66]

title: Air Force Safety Awards Program
content: Recognizes individuals, teams, and units for outstanding contributions to mishap prevention and safety programs. [65, 66]
bullets: Governed by the **DAF Safety Awards Guide** and overseen by the Chief of Safety. [67]
Categories cover flight, ground, weapons, and space safety. [66, 67]
Recognizes both sustained superior performance and one-time acts that averted serious mishaps. [67]

title: Volunteer Service Award
content: DoD-level service medal recognizing members for substantial, sustained volunteer service to the civilian or military family community. [68]
bullets: Established by **Executive Order 12830**. [68]
Volunteer service must be significant with tangible results and reflect favorably on the DoD. [68]
Sustained is generally interpreted as approximately **3 years and/or 500+ hours**. [69]
Typical activities include work with charities, emergency services, or youth programs. [69]

title: General John P. Jumper Award for Excellence in Warfighting Integration
content: Recognizes individuals for outstanding contributions to the integration of Air Force warfighting and operations support capabilities. [69, 70]
bullets: Named for the 17th Chief of Staff of the Air Force, who institutionalized warfighting integration functions. [71, 72]
Awarded in three categories: officer, enlisted, and civilian. [72]
Honors sustained superior performance in integrating capabilities that **shorten the kill chain**. [72]
Open to personnel in any career field contributing to information dominance. [73]

title: Major General Harold M. Grant Award
content: Recognizes a small communications squadron for sustained excellence and contributions to the communication mission. [71, 73]
bullets: Presented to units typically having fewer than **125 personnel**. [73]
Evaluates mission support across voice, data, cyber, and deployed communications. [74]
Criteria include leadership, team performance, and impact on the supported mission. [75]

title: A1 Community Awards (Manpower, Personnel, and Services)
content: A broad program recognizing individuals, teams, and units for outstanding contributions in the personnel and services career fields. [74, 76]
bullets: Administered by **AF/A1** (Deputy Chief of Staff for Manpower, Personnel and Services). [77]
Includes installation awards for best large and small Force Support Squadrons. [77]
Recognizes excellence in force development, mortuary affairs, and overall FSS operations. [77]

title: Lieutenant General William H. Tunner Award
content: Recognizes the most outstanding airlift crew in the United States Air Force. [78, 79]
bullets: Named for the key architect of modern military airlift, known for leading the **Berlin Airlift**. [78, 79]
Awarded to a multi-member crew demonstrating exceptional skill and risk management. [78, 80]
Highlights performance during missions like humanitarian relief or combat operations. [78, 80]

title: Air Force Vehicle Management Awards
content: Recognizes individuals and flights for excellence in the management and maintenance of the vehicle fleet. [80, 81]
bullets: Assess fleet mission-capable rates, safety performance, and innovation in logistics. [82]
Includes specialized support for **POTUS movements** and flying units. [82]
Part of the Logistics Readiness Awards program. [81]

title: Air Force Financial Management and Comptroller Awards
content: Recognizes individuals and teams for outstanding performance and stewardship in the financial management career field. [83, 84]
bullets: Criteria cover fiscal stewardship, auditability, and innovative business processes. [85]
Awards are announced annually by the **Assistant Secretary of the Air Force (FM&C)**. [84]
Individual awards are categorized by rank and civilian grade. [86]

title: The Thomas Castleman Award (Outstanding Paralegal of the Year)
content: Recognizes the most outstanding paralegal in the Air Force for contributions to the JAG Corps mission. [85, 86]
bullets: Named for the **first Chief Master Sergeant** appointed to the paralegal career field. [87, 88]
Paralegal awards honor superior initiative, technical skill, and professionalism in legal support. [88]
Winners' names are displayed at the **Air Force JAG School**. [88]

title: AFA Verne Orr Award
content: Recognizes the Air Force unit that makes the most effective use of its human resources to accomplish the mission. [87, 89]
bullets: Evaluates manpower utilization, innovation in organizing work, and cross-training. [90]
The award is based on unit accomplishments during the preceding calendar year. [91]
Recognizes programs that enhance professional development and quality of life. [91]

title: AFSOC Lambertsen Award
content: Recognizes individuals or teams whose audacity, insight, and ingenuity produce significant operational innovations for SOF. [90, 92]
bullets: Named for **Dr. Christian J. Lambertsen**, the 'Father of the Frogmen'. [92, 93]
One of AFSOC's highest honors, recognizing major positive and enduring mission impact. [92]
Recognizes teams who identify problems and **rapidly field practical, scalable solutions**. [93]

title: Air Force Special Warfare (AFSPECWAR) Awards
content: Functional community awards recognizing Special Warfare operators and instructors for exceptional performance in their specialties. [94, 95]
bullets: Recognizes top performers in fields like Combat Control, Pararescue, and TACP. [95]
Criteria emphasize leadership, training impact, and direct support to joint SOF missions. [96]
Winners are usually recognized at **Special Warfare ceremonies**. [96]

title: AFSOC Individual Awards Program
content: A comprehensive program recognizing the exceptional achievements of individuals throughout AFSOC. [96, 97]
bullets: Encompasses annual awards for different rank tiers and civilian employees. [98, 99]
Recipients are recognized at the **AFSOC Outstanding Airmen of the Year banquet**. [99]
Evaluation covers duty performance in special operations missions and leadership. [99]

title: Air Force Organizational Excellence Award (AFOEA)
content: Recognizes exceptionally meritorious service or outstanding achievement by unnumbered Air Force units or organizations. [100, 101]
bullets: Typically awarded to organizations at the directorate, division, or MAJCOM level. [100]
Performance must clearly set the unit apart from similar units. [100]
Personnel assigned during the award period are authorized to wear the **AFOEA ribbon**. [100]
Often used at local levels for internal awards with criteria defined by MAJCOM-specific instructions. [102]
